abstract.para: &hawk; allows you to monitor and administer a &ha; cluster from any machine that can connect to the cluster nodes, using a graphical Web browser. You can also configure a virtual IP address that allows clients to connect to the &hawk; service no matter which node the service is running on.

listitem.para: The client machine must be able to connect to the cluster nodes.
The client machine must have a graphical Web browser with JavaScript and cookies enabled.
The cluster setup script creates a user named hacluster with a default password. Change this password to a secure one as soon as possible.

The cluster setup script generates a self-signed default private key and certificate by default. If you want to use your own certificate, replace the generated certificate at /etc/ssl/certs/hawk.pem with your own. &hawk; supports wild card certificates as well as conventional certificates.

topic.para: You can perform this procedure on any machine that can connect to the cluster nodes:

step.para: Start a Web browser and enter the following URL:
Replace HAWKSERVER with the IP address or host name of a cluster node, or the &hawk; virtual IP address if one is configured.

note.title: Certificate warning
note.para: If a certificate warning appears when you try to access the URL for the first time, a self-signed certificate is in use. Self-signed certificates are not considered trustworthy by default.
To verify the certificate, ask your cluster operator for the certificate details.
To proceed anyway, you can add an exception in the browser to bypass the warning.

step.para: On the &hawk; login screen, enter the Username and Password of the hacluster user.
Click Log In. The &hawk; Web interface shows the Status screen by default.

textobject.phrase: The Status screen shows one configured resource: the virtual IP address admin-ip, running on a node called &node1;.
